sir.read_chi2(filename, task='')[source]#

Reads the last chi value in a inv.chi file

Parameters:

  • filename (string) – Path of the chi file

  • task (string, optional) – Prints out in which folder the chi2 file does not exist. Default: ‘’

Returns:

out – Best chi2 value of the fit

Return type:

float

sir.read_model(filename)[source]#

Reads a model file and returns all parameters

Parameters:

filename (string) – String containing the path of the file

Returns:

  • out (numpy.array) – Log tau

  • out (numpy.array) – Temperature in K

  • out (numpy.array) – Electron pressure in dyn/cm^2

  • out (numpy.array) – Microturbulence velocity in cm/s

  • out (numpy.array) – Magnetic field strength in Gauss

  • out (numpy.array) – Line-of-sight velocity in cm/s

  • out (numpy.array) – Inclination in deg

  • out (numpy.array) – Azimuth angle in deg

  • out (numpy.array, optional) – Height in km

  • otu (numpy.array, optional) – Gas pressure in dyn/cm^2

  • out (numpy.array, optional) – Density in g/cm^3

sir.read_profile(filename, num=0)[source]#

Reads the first LINE data from a profile computed by SIR

Parameters:

  • filename (string) – String containing the path of the file

  • num (int, optional) – Number of the line which is loaded. Default: 0 (use first one from line)

Returns:

  • out (numpy.array) – Wavelengths in A

  • out (numpy.array) – Stokes I

  • out (numpy.array) – Stokes Q

  • out (numpy.array) – Stokes U

  • out (numpy.array) – Stokes V

sir.write_gauss_psf(sigma, filename)[source]#

Writes the spectral point spread function with the given sigma. This function is used when the field psf in the config contains ‘gauss 1.0’ with sigma = 1.0 mA in this example.

Parameters:

  • sigma (float) – Sigma of the Gauss function in mA

  • filename (str) – Output file name

Return type:

None

sir.write_model(filename, Header, log_tau, T, Pe, v_micro, B, vlos, inc, azimuth, z=None, Pg=None, rho=None)[source]#

Write a model with the given data in a specific format. Note that negative values have one white space less

Parameters:

  • filename (string) – Name of the saved file

  • Header (string) – Header of the model

  • log_tau (numpy.array) – Log tau

  • T (numpy.array) – Temperature in K

  • Pe (numpy.array) – Electron pressure in dyn/cm^2

  • v_micro (numpy.array) – Microturbulence velocity in cm/s

  • B (numpy.array) – Magnetic field strength in Gauss

  • vlos (numpy.array) – Line-of-sight velocity in cm/s

  • inc (numpy.array) – Inclination in deg

  • azimuth (numpy.array) – Azimuth angle in deg

  • z (numpy.array, optional) – Height in km

  • Pg (numpy.array, optional) – Gas pressure in dyn/cm^2

  • rho (numpy.array, optional) – Density in g/cm^3

Return type:

None

  • pos (int) – Position which model is saved

misc.py#

Miscellaneous functions

misc.create_task_folder_list(arg)[source]#

Creates a list which folders should be created and executed. This is done so that the inversion itself can be executed linearly to make use of all cores.

Parameters:

arg (numpy array or int) – 1x4 array containing the limits in x and y of the data or number of 1D models

Returns:

out – Dictionary with all the names of the task folders, x and y position

Return type:

dict
